conclusion: Two sliders A and B, each with mass m, are connected by a light rope and placed on an inclined plane with an angle θ = 37°. A constant horizontal force F is applied to slider B to the right, and both sliders are on the verge of not sliding upwards. The coefficient of kinetic friction is μ = 0.5, and the maximum static friction is equal to the kinetic friction. Gravitational acceleration is g. It is known that sin 37° = 0.6.
The image shows two sliders A and B connected by a rope on an inclined plane with an angle of 37°. Slider B is being pulled by a horizontal force F to the right.
The problem requires finding the magnitude of the external force F.

Slider A has forces acting on it: gravitational force mg (downward), normal force NA (perpendicular to the incline), tension T (upward along the incline), and frictional force fA (downward along the incline).

Slider B has forces acting on it: gravitational force mg (downward), normal force NB (perpendicular to the incline), tension T' (downward along the incline), frictional force fB (to the left), and the external force F (to the right).

premise: The component of the gravitational force along the incline for slider A is mg sin 37° = 0.6mg.
conclusion: The gravitational force component along the incline for slider A is 0.6mg.

premise: The frictional force for slider A is fA = μNA cos 37° = 0.5NA cos 37°.
conclusion: The frictional force for slider A is 0.5NA cos 37°.

premise: The equation of motion along the incline for slider A is T - mg sin 37° - fA = 0. Substituting fA = 0.5NA cos 37°, we get T = 0.6mg + 0.5NA cos 37°.
conclusion: The tension in the rope for slider A is T = 0.6mg + 0.5NA cos 37°.

premise: The component of the gravitational force along the incline for slider B is mg sin 37° = 0.6mg.
conclusion: The gravitational force component along the incline for slider B is 0.6mg.

premise: The frictional force for slider B is fB = μNB cos 37° = 0.5NB cos 37°.
conclusion: The frictional force for slider B is 0.5NB cos 37°.

premise: The equation of motion along the incline for slider B is F - T' - mg sin 37° - fB = 0. Substituting fB = 0.5NB cos 37°, we get F - T' - 0.6mg - 0.5NB cos 37° = 0.
conclusion: The equation of motion for slider B is F - T' - 0.6mg - 0.5NB cos 37° = 0.
